Understate: The claim "Only three in 10 young Americans under 30 -- 30 percent under 30 -- have full-time work" is understated because the actual percentage of young Americans with full-time work is higher.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based on a misinterpretation of the data from the report, as pointed out by the expert.
Problematic assumption: The claim is based on the assumption that the remaining 31.7 percent who were employed had a full-time job, which is not accurate according to the expert's analysis.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert provides an alternative explanation by stating that when all Americans in that age group are considered, about 43 percent have full-time jobs, which contradicts the claim.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the actual percentage of young Americans with full-time work is higher than the stated 30 percent.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times as it is based on a misinterpretation of the data and does not accurately represent the employment situation of young Americans.
Exaggerate: There is no evidence of exaggeration in the claim.
